item.title: Local Nets
item.description:
Local Nets

A guide to amateur radio nets in and around Rowan County, NC. VHF/UHF nets listed are within approximately 30 miles of Salisbury. 10 meter and HF nets with broader reach are listed separately.

Always verify frequencies and schedules before checking in. Nets may change without notice.

Rowan County

10 Meter and HF Nets

These nets have a broader reach and can often be accessed from Rowan County on HF.

item.title: What is an Elmer?
item.description:
What is an Elmer?

An “Elmer” in ham radio is an experienced, often volunteer mentor who provides personalized guidance, technical knowledge, and encouragement to newcomers or those looking to advance their skills. Coined in 1971 by Rod Newkirk to honor his own mentor, the term is unique to amateur radio and signifies the supportive, peer-to-peer education that is crucial for navigating the hobby.

Key Aspects of an Elmer

  • Role: Mentors, tutors, and guides new operators, often helping them earn their license and set up their first station.
  • Origin: Coined in the March 1971 “How’s DX” column of QST magazine by Rod Newkirk (W9BRD), referring to his mentor, Elmer P. Frohardt Jr.
  • Context: Used as both a noun (the person) and a verb (“Elmering” someone).
  • Finding One: Often found through local amateur radio clubs like RARS.
  • Purpose: Provides hands-on assistance with radio operations, technical skills, and navigating the nuances of the hobby.

Need an Elmer?

The Rowan Amateur Radio Society has experienced operators who are happy to help newcomers get started. Whether you need help studying for your license, setting up your first radio, or figuring out antennas, we’re here to help.

item.title: About RARS
item.description:
About Us

The Rowan Amateur Radio Society (RARS) is an amateur radio club serving Rowan County, North Carolina. Operating under the call sign N4UH, the club proudly represents the society on the airwaves from its home in Salisbury.

Meetings

RARS meets on the 2nd Monday of each month at 7:00 PM at:

Rowan County Rescue Squad, 1140 Julian Rd, Salisbury, NC 28146

Officers

  • President: David Jackman N7WOY
  • Vice President: Michael Zinicola WD4PVS
  • Secretary: Doug Bowers KR4HIL
  • Treasurer: James “Jim” Russell KR4FHI

Repeaters

RARS maintains two repeaters under the N4UH call sign:

item.title: Activities & Events
item.description:
Activities & Events

Stay up to date with RARS activities and events! Check out our calendar below for upcoming meetings, hamfests, field days, and other club activities.

Club Calendar

item.title: ARES and Emergency Communications
item.description:
RARS ARES

Communications and Disaster Preparedness

When emergencies strike Rowan County, reliable communication becomes essential. The Rowan Amateur Radio Society (RARS) ARES team plays a critical role in ensuring that emergency managers, public safety agencies, and community partners have dependable backup communication when traditional systems fail or become overloaded.

“We hope we’re never needed – but we train like we will be.”

ARES in Rowan County: A Mission of Service

RARS ARES volunteers are FCC licensed amateur radio operators trained to provide supplemental communication during disasters, severe weather, and major public events. Their work supports Rowan County Emergency Management and the broader Salisbury region.

item.title: Contact Us
item.description:
Contact Us

You can reach the Rowan Amateur Radio Society by:

Phone: (704) 433-7371

Meeting Location: Rowan County Rescue Squad 1140 Julian Rd Salisbury, NC 28146

We meet on the 2nd Monday of each month at 7:00 PM. Visitors are always welcome!

On the Air

Listen for us on the N4UH repeaters:

  • 2m: 145.410 MHz, -0.600 offset, 136.5 PL
  • 70cm: 443.250 MHz, +5.000 offset, 136.5 PL

Contact Form

Please enter a valid email address.

item.title: Helpful Links
item.description:
Helpful Links

A collection of useful resources for amateur radio operators, from our club pages to licensing information, equipment retailers, and more.

RARS Resources

  • RARS on ARRL - Our club listing on the ARRL website
  • N4UH Broadcastify Feed - Listen to the N4UH repeater online

Licensing & Testing

Study Resources

  • HamStudy.org - Free online study materials and practice exams
  • ARRL Exam Session Search - Find a license exam near you
  • ARRL Getting Licensed - Official guide to getting your ham license

License Lookup

  • FCC License Search (ULS) - Look up any amateur radio license in the FCC database

Nearby VE Testing Sessions

  • Mecklenburg ARS (Charlotte) - Charlotte area testing
  • Richmond County ARC - Rockingham area testing
  • Five County Ham Radio Enthusiasts - Raleigh/Fuquay-Varina area

Equipment Retailers

Major Online Retailers

  • Ham Radio Outlet (HRO) - World’s largest ham radio supplier with stores nationwide
  • DX Engineering - Quality equipment, antennas, and accessories
  • GigaParts - Amateur radio, computers, and electronics

Used Equipment

  • QRZ Swapmeet - Buy/sell used ham radio equipment
  • eHam Classifieds - Used equipment listings

Organizations

  • ARRL - American Radio Relay League (National Association for Amateur Radio)
  • ARES - Amateur Radio Emergency Service
  • SKYWARN - NWS severe weather spotter program

Technical Resources

  • QRZ.com - Callsign lookup and ham radio community
  • RepeaterBook - Repeater directory for North America
  • APRS.fi - APRS tracking and mapping
  • PSK Reporter - Digital mode propagation reporting
  • DX Summit - DX cluster spots
  • GMRS (FCC) - General Mobile Radio Service information
  • NCMesh - North Carolina mesh networking community

Propagation & Conditions

  • NOAA Space Weather - Solar and geomagnetic conditions
  • HF Propagation - HF propagation prediction
  • DX Heat Map - Real-time DX activity

Discord Communities

  • OARC - Online Amateur Radio Community - Large online ham radio community
  • HHRC - Ham Radio Crash Course - Ham Radio Crash Course Discord server
  • The HamShack - General ham radio discussion server

Find more ham radio Discord servers at Disboard.

item.title: Join Us
item.description:
Join Us

Thinking about getting into amateur radio? Already licensed and looking for a local crew? The Rowan Amateur Radio Society (RARS) is a great place to plug in. We’re a relaxed, friendly group that enjoys learning, experimenting, and helping each other out – on the air and in person.

Why Join RARS

You’ll Find a Community. Ham radio is more fun with people around you. At RARS, you’ll meet operators of all experience levels who are happy to share ideas, answer questions, and swap stories.

item.title: Live Repeater Feed
item.description:
Listen Live

You can listen to the N4UH repeater live through Broadcastify. This feed covers the RARS repeater system in Rowan County, NC.

Listen on Broadcastify

About the Feed

This Broadcastify feed streams audio from the N4UH 2-meter repeater operated by the Rowan Amateur Radio Society:

  • 2m Repeater: 145.410 MHz, -0.600 offset, 136.5 PL

Note: Only the 2m repeater is streamed on Broadcastify. The 70cm repeater (443.250 MHz) is not included in this feed.

item.title: Local Repeaters
item.description:
Local Repeaters

A quick reference guide to amateur radio repeaters in and around Rowan County, NC. This list includes repeaters within approximately 30 miles of Salisbury.

Data sourced from RepeaterBook. Always verify frequencies before use.

Rowan County

N4UH - Rowan Amateur Radio Society (Salisbury)

Band Frequency Offset Tone Notes
2m 145.410 MHz -0.600 136.5 PL Primary club repeater
70cm 443.250 MHz +5.000 136.5 PL Secondary repeater

Cabarrus County

W4BFB - Mecklenburg ARS (Concord Area)

Band Frequency Offset Tone Notes
2m 146.940 MHz -0.600 100.0 PL

N4CSI (Concord)

Band Frequency Offset Tone Notes
2m 147.315 MHz +0.600 131.8 PL

Davidson County

W4DP (Lexington)

Band Frequency Offset Tone Notes
2m 146.685 MHz -0.600 82.5 PL
70cm 444.200 MHz +5.000 82.5 PL

N4YDU (Thomasville)

Band Frequency Offset Tone Notes
2m 147.390 MHz +0.600 100.0 PL

Iredell County

N4IRS (Statesville)

Band Frequency Offset Tone Notes
2m 146.760 MHz -0.600 100.0 PL
70cm 444.725 MHz +5.000 100.0 PL

W4MVB (Mooresville)

Band Frequency Offset Tone Notes
2m 145.230 MHz -0.600 100.0 PL

Stanly County

W4UA (Albemarle)

Band Frequency Offset Tone Notes
2m 147.120 MHz +0.600 91.5 PL

Mecklenburg County

W4BFB - Mecklenburg ARS (Charlotte)

Band Frequency Offset Tone Notes
2m 146.940 MHz -0.600 100.0 PL Large coverage area
70cm 444.000 MHz +5.000 100.0 PL

N4NC (Charlotte)

Band Frequency Offset Tone Notes
2m 145.350 MHz -0.600 118.8 PL

Randolph County

W4RAT (Asheboro)

Band Frequency Offset Tone Notes
2m 147.255 MHz +0.600 88.5 PL

Programming Tips

  • Most modern radios can store these as memory channels
  • Always verify the tone (PL/CTCSS) is correct before transmitting
  • Standard offsets: 2m uses +/- 0.600 MHz, 70cm uses +/- 5.000 MHz
  • Negative offset (-) means transmit frequency is lower than receive

Online Resources

  • RepeaterBook - North Carolina - Complete NC repeater database
  • ARRL Repeater Directory - Official ARRL listings

Know of a repeater that should be listed here? Contact us with the details!

item.title: Meetings
item.description:
Meeting Schedule

The Rowan Amateur Radio Society meets on the 2nd Monday of each month at 7:00 PM.

Location

Rowan County Rescue Squad 1140 Julian Rd Salisbury, NC 28146

Get Directions on Google Maps

What to Expect

Our meetings typically include:

  • Club business and announcements
  • Technical presentations or demonstrations
  • Discussion of upcoming events and activities
  • Time for socializing and Q&A

Visitors are always welcome! Whether you’re a licensed ham or just curious about amateur radio, come on by and say hello.

item.title: Membership Application
item.description:
Join RARS

Thank you for your interest in joining the Rowan Amateur Radio Society! Whether you’re a newly licensed ham or an experienced operator, we welcome you to our club.

Membership is open to all - you don’t need to be licensed to join, but active participation in club activities is encouraged.

You can apply online using the form below, or download the membership application (PDF) and bring it with you to the next meeting.

item.title: Privacy Policy
item.description:
RARS Website Privacy Policy

The Rowan Amateur Radio Society (RARS) is committed to respecting and protecting your privacy. This policy explains how information is collected and used when you visit the RARS website at www.rowanars.net. By using this website, you consent to the practices described below.

Information Collected Automatically

When you visit the RARS website, limited technical information may be collected automatically, such as the date and time of your visit, your IP address, and the type of web browser used. This information is anonymous and is not personally identifiable. It is used solely to help us understand how the website is used – for example, which pages are visited most often and how long visitors remain on the site. This data is reviewed only in aggregate and not at the individual level.

item.title: Repeaters
item.description:
Repeaters

The Rowan Amateur Radio Society (RARS) operates a repeater system under the call sign N4UH that serves as a vital communication hub for amateur radio operators across Rowan County and surrounding areas. More than just a technical asset, the RARS repeater is a community resource that supports daily radio activity, emergency readiness, and public service communication.

N4UH Repeater Frequencies

Band Frequency Offset PL Tone
2 Meter 145.410 MHz -0.600 MHz 136.5 Hz
70 Centimeter 443.250 MHz +5.000 MHz 136.5 Hz

Extending Communication Across the Region

A repeater receives a signal on one frequency and retransmits it on another, dramatically increasing the range of handheld and mobile radios. For local hams, the RARS repeater provides:

item.title: Silent Keys
item.description:
Silent Keys

In amateur radio, we honor those who have passed on as “Silent Keys” – a reference to the Morse code key that has gone quiet. These operators dedicated themselves to the hobby, to public service, and to the fellowship of amateur radio.

The Rowan Amateur Radio Society remembers and honors our members who have become Silent Keys. Their contributions to our club and to the amateur radio community will not be forgotten.
